TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   HPI:
   24 Hour Events:
   CC: s/p esophageal stent placment admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for respiratory
   distress
   .
   HPI: This is a 74 year old female with recently diagnosed gastric CA,
   s/p resection transfered from [**Hospital3 4838**] for esophageal
   stenting, now admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] after intubation for respiratory stress.
   The follow history is taken from [**Hospital1 **] and [**Hospital1 **] notes. The
   patient underwent EGD in [**2113-9-30**] for w/u anemia. She was found to
   have a gastric mass, poorly differentiated adenocarinoma. On [**11-1**], she
   underwent partial proximal gastrectomy and pylorplasty with J-tube
   placment. She was discharged home on [**11-9**] but returned to the ED later
   that day for hematemasis. EGD was done showing some clots in the
   stomach but no active bleeding. The follwing day she had another
   episode of hematemasis, was transfered to the ICU and electively
   intubated for airway protection.  She underwent repeat endoscopy which
   showed a small separtion in one portion of the esophagastric anatomosis
   with oozing. She then underwent exlap on [**11-11**] where a tear in the
   capusle of the spleen was found, but was not able to be repaired given
   concerns with disrupting the anastomosis. [**Female First Name (un) **] was controlled with
   thombin-soaked Gel foam, bleeding stopped. She then underwent an
   arteriogram showing a 6mm splnic pseuoaneurysm. She was transfussed
   multipe unitls during these few days, HCT around 26. She was on Zosyn
   and fluconazol 200mg IV daily.
   .
   She was transfered to [**Hospital1 **] SICU for treatment on the pseudoaneurysm.
   She was taken to IR for stenting of of splenic artery aneursym. She was
   weaned off the ventilator. However, she was noted to be on 3L NC duirng
   ambulance transport. Lasix was given. There was a question of vomiting
   enroute. She was then reintubated on [**11-18**] for respiratory distress and
   hypotension on [**11-18**]. She was diuresed for the following two days and
   then extubated on [**11-20**]. On [**11-20**], she underwent CT chest, which only
   showed moderate pleural effusions. On [**11-22**], she was switched from
   Zosyn to Cefepime.
   .
   During this time a CT abdomen, demonstrated perforation of the GE
   junction by the NG tube. NGT was pulled back and secured.Gastrografin
   swallow  on [**2113-11-23**] showed a contained anastomotic leak to the left of
   the remaining stomach measuring approx 6x3cm. She was then transfered
   to [**Hospital1 1**] for esophagastric stenting.
   .
   Here she underwent ERCP with placement of esophagastric metal 9cm x10mm
   stent proximal clipping. She stent placement was verified by a
   pediatric scope. She had been electively intubated prior to the
   procedure and was extubated post ERCP. Post proceedure, she was
   ordered125ml/hr NS; she likely received 400cc LR during the procedure.
   She then developed respiratory distress with respiratory rates in 40's,
   no documented hypoxia.  She was then reintubated in the PACU. She was
   given lasix 20mg IV in the PACU. She was transfered to the floor on AC
   500x 14, FI02 50%, PEEP 5.
   .
   ROS: unable to obtain
   .
   PMH:
   gastric CA s/p resection
   breast ca s/p mastectomy
   partial thyroidectomy for thyroid CA
   bladder CA s/p transurethral resection
   HTN
   Splenic artery aneurysm s/p stenting
   .
   Home Medications:
   Arimidex 1mg daily
   Diovan 80mg daily
   ASA 81mg daily
   Prilosec 20mg da day
   Carafate 1 gram per day
   Calcium
   Vit D
   Toprol Xl 50mg daily
   .
   Medications on Transfer:
   Albuterol
   Ipratropium
   Cefepime 1gram q12
   Fluconazole 200mg IV once a day
   Heparin 5000 units TID
   hydromorphine 0.6mg -1,g q2-4hrs PRN pain
   Reglan 5mg IV q 6hrs
   lopressor 75mg [**Hospital1 **]
   Zofran 5mg IV q 6hrs
   Percocet 5mg
   protonix 40mg q12hrs
   Insulin sliding scale
   Diovan 80mg qhs via j-tube
   ASA 81mg via J-tube
   .
   Allergies: Percocet, Tape
   .
   Social History: Married and lives with her husband, children live
   nearby, she is a former smoker of less than one pack per day, she
   drinks wine occaisonally
   .
   Family History: breast ca, sister with gastric CA, a sister with lung
   CA, CAD and COPD in various family members
   .
   Physical Exam:
   Vitals: T:99.4 P: 88 BP:138/61 R: 14 SaO2: 98& F102 50%
   General: intubated sedasted
   HEENT: MMM, no lesions noted in OP, no JVD
   Pulmonary: Lungs CTA bilaterally
   Cardiac: RRR, nl. S1S2, no M/R/G noted
   Abdomen: soft, NT/ND, hypoactive bowel sounds, midline healing incision
   with slight erythema but no edema or drainag, JP inplace with minimal
   serous fluid, J-tube in place with some yellow discharge but no edema
   Extremities: No C/C/E bilaterally, 2+ radial, DP and PT pulses b/l.
   Skin: no rashes or lesions noted.
   Neurologic:
   -mental status: intubated sedate, occ opens eyes, moving her head and
   coughing but not moving extremities
   .
   Laboratory Data: see below
   .
   EKG [**Hospital1 **] [**11-6**]: sinus tachy at 106, left axis, deep TWI in
   V2-V3,  TWF in V4-V6, I, AVL, ? q waves in III, AVF, no ST elevations
   or depressions
   EKG [**Hospital1 1**]: TWI in V2-V6
   .
   Radiologic Data:
   - CXR [**Hospital1 1**]: pulmonary edema, small left sided efffusion
   - CXR [**11-24**] from [**Hospital1 **]: mild edema, left pleural effusion
   -CT abd w/ contrast [**11-20**]:
   1. extraluminal gas collection to the lefto the body of the somach, NG
   tubes through an area of surgical clips in the GE junction into this
   extraluminal gas collection, findings compatible with perforation at
   the GE junction
   2. retroperitoneal hematoma in the right anterio pararenal space
   3. J-tube in place
   - Bilateral LENI's [**11-20**]: no DVT avobe the knees
   - Gastrografin swallow [**2113-11-23**]:  contained anastomotic leak to the
   left of the remaining stomack measuring approx 6x3cm
   -  CT Chest [**11-20**]: no PE, bilateral moderal pleural effusion L>R
   Allergies:
   Adhesive Tape (Topical)
   itching;
   Percocet (Oral) (Oxycodone Hcl/Acetaminophen)
   itching;
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Cefipime - [**2113-11-24**] 09:15 PM
   Infusions:

   Other ICU medications:
   Fentanyl - [**2113-11-24**] 11:30 PM

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 74 year old female with recently diagnosed gastric CA, s/p
   resection transfered from [**Hospital3 4838**] for esophageal stenting,
   now admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] after intubation for respiratory stress.
   .
   # Respiratory distress: Characterized as tachypnea. This is the fourth
   time she has been intubated - 1) hematemasis 2) respiratory distress 3)
   for ERCP 4)respiratory distress. Per the family, she had significant
   anxiety on one extubation to the extent that she needed to be
   reintubated immediately [**2-13**] distress; she was anxious that her husband
   was not present. This level of anxiety may have resulted in
   reintubation today. However, there is also evidence of volume overload
   on CXR and given the rapidity with which she went into distress, she
   may have had flash pulmonary edema. No PNA, no sputum production, fever
   or leukocytosis. No hypoxia on ABG. Of note, she was sat'ing 98% on 3L
   NC prior to ERCP.
   - intubated, propofol and fentanyl
   - diurese with lasix 10mg IV, f/u UOP
   - nebs
   - [**Month (only) 202**] Fi02
   - RSBI and SBT in am
   - may need ativan peri-extubation and family at bedside
   - consider peri-extubation CPAP and nitro drip
   - echo for ? diastolic dsyfunction
   .
   # Anastamotic leak: s/p stenting
   - cefepime day 2, fluconazole
   .
   # S/p gastrectomy:
   - J-tube and tube feeds
   - fentanyl boluses for pain while intubated, but will transition back
   to percocet and dilauded
   .
   # TWI on EKG: same as prior
   - will not r/o
   .
   # HTN
   - cont metoprolol and diovan
   .
   #) Prophylaxis: PPI, sc heparin
   .
   #) FEN: TF, NPO
   .
   #) Access: PIVs, TLC, a-line
   .
   #) Code Status: Full
   .
   #) Dispo: pending further work-up and treatment
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2113-11-24**] 07:29 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2113-11-24**] 07:30 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots, SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
   Need for restraints reviewed
   Comments:
   Communication: Family meeting held , ICU consent signed Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old female with a history of gastric cancer, who underwent resection and was transferred to the ICU for respiratory distress. She has undergone several interventions, including esophageal stenting, ERCP, and gastrectomy. She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient has a history of anxiety and has been reintubated multiple times due to respiratory distress.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Anastomotic leak: The patient has a contained anastomotic leak to the left of the remaining stomach, which may lead to further complications such as abscess formation, sepsis, or fistula.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress may lead to further complications such as pneumonia, respiratory failure, or cardiac arrest.
3. Sepsis: The patient's history of hematemesis and recent surgical procedures may increase her risk of developing sepsis.
4. Pulmonary edema: The patient's rapid onset of respiratory distress and volume overload on CXR may indicate flash pulmonary edema, which can lead to further complications such as cardiac arrest or respiratory failure.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of hypertension and recent surgery may increase her risk of developing cardiac complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, or myocardial infarction.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's history of anxiety and recent sedation may increase her risk of developing neurological complications such as seizures, delirium, or cognitive impairment.
7. Infection: The patient's history of recent surgery and indwelling catheters may increase her risk of developing infection, such as urinary tract infection, pneumonia, or surgical site infection.
8. Bleeding: The patient's history of hematemesis and recent surgery may increase her risk of bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or intracranial bleeding.
9. Malnutrition: The patient's history of gastrectomy and recent surgery may increase her risk of malnutrition, which can lead to further complications such as delayed wound healing, infection, or decreased immune function.
10. Psychological complications: The patient's history of anxiety and recent sedation may increase her risk of developing psychological complications such as depression, anxiety, or post-traumatic stress disorder.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. She is at risk of developing respiratory failure, sepsis, and cardiac complications. The plan is to continue diuresis with lasix, monitor her respiratory status, and consider extubation once her respiratory status improves. The patient's anastomotic leak will be monitored, and further interventions will be considered as necessary. The patient's nutritional status will be assessed, and enteral nutrition will be considered if necessary. The patient's psychological status will be monitored, and counseling will be considered if necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of gastric cancer, who underwent resection and is now admitted to the ICU for respiratory distress. She was intubated for respiratory stress and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 93 bpm, and blood pressure of 81/48 mmHg. Her oxygen saturation is 99% on 50% FiO2. She is sedated and intubated, but arousable to voice commands.

The patient's laboratory results show mild leukocytosis and low-grade fevers, which may indicate an infectious process. However, the CXR is still wet, and the patient may need further diuresis.

The patient has several potential medical complications, including:

1. Respiratory distress: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and she may need further diuresis to manage fluid overload.
2. Anastamotic leak: The patient's recent surgery may have led to anastamotic leak, which could lead to further complications.
3. Sepsis: The patient's mild leukocytosis and low-grade fevers may indicate an infectious process, which could lead to sepsis.
4. Diastolic dysfunction: The patient's echocardiogram may show diastolic dysfunction, which could lead to further complications.
5. Anasthetic complications: The patient's recent surgery may have led to anesthetic complications, such as respiratory depression or cardiac arrest.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Weaning of sedation and FiO2
2. Further diuresis to manage fluid overload
3. Antibiotics for potential infectious process
4. Echocardiogram to evaluate for diastolic dysfunction
5. Repeat EKG to monitor cardiac status
6. Repeat CXR to monitor respiratory status
7. Follow-up on laboratory results to monitor for potential complications.

In summary, the patient is a 74-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of gastric cancer, who is admitted to the ICU for respiratory distress. She has several potential medical complications, including respiratory distress, anastamotic leak, sepsis, diastolic dysfunction, and anesthetic complications. Her plan of care includes weaning of sedation and FiO2, further diuresis, antibiotics, echocardiogram, repeat EKG, and repeat CXR.

TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   HPI:
   24 Hour Events:
   CC: s/p esophageal stent placment admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for respiratory
   distress
   .
   HPI: This is a 74 year old female with recently diagnosed gastric CA,
   s/p resection transfered from [**Hospital3 4838**] for esophageal
   stenting, now admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] after intubation for respiratory stress.
   The follow history is taken from [**Hospital1 **] and [**Hospital1 **] notes. The
   patient underwent EGD in [**2113-9-30**] for w/u anemia. She was found to
   have a gastric mass, poorly differentiated adenocarinoma. On [**11-1**], she
   underwent partial proximal gastrectomy and pylorplasty with J-tube
   placment. She was discharged home on [**11-9**] but returned to the ED later
   that day for hematemasis. EGD was done showing some clots in the
   stomach but no active bleeding. The follwing day she had another
   episode of hematemasis, was transfered to the ICU and electively
   intubated for airway protection.  She underwent repeat endoscopy which
   showed a small separtion in one portion of the esophagastric anatomosis
   with oozing. She then underwent exlap on [**11-11**] where a tear in the
   capusle of the spleen was found, but was not able to be repaired given
   concerns with disrupting the anastomosis. [**Female First Name (un) **] was controlled with
   thombin-soaked Gel foam, bleeding stopped. She then underwent an
   arteriogram showing a 6mm splnic pseuoaneurysm. She was transfussed
   multipe unitls during these few days, HCT around 26. She was on Zosyn
   and fluconazol 200mg IV daily.
   .
   She was transfered to [**Hospital1 **] SICU for treatment on the pseudoaneurysm.
   She was taken to IR for stenting of of splenic artery aneursym. She was
   weaned off the ventilator. However, she was noted to be on 3L NC duirng
   ambulance transport. Lasix was given. There was a question of vomiting
   enroute. She was then reintubated on [**11-18**] for respiratory distress and
   hypotension on [**11-18**]. She was diuresed for the following two days and
   then extubated on [**11-20**]. On [**11-20**], she underwent CT chest, which only
   showed moderate pleural effusions. On [**11-22**], she was switched from
   Zosyn to Cefepime.
   .
   During this time a CT abdomen, demonstrated perforation of the GE
   junction by the NG tube. NGT was pulled back and secured.Gastrografin
   swallow  on [**2113-11-23**] showed a contained anastomotic leak to the left of
   the remaining stomach measuring approx 6x3cm. She was then transfered
   to [**Hospital1 1**] for esophagastric stenting.
   .
   Here she underwent ERCP with placement of esophagastric metal 9cm x10mm
   stent proximal clipping. She stent placement was verified by a
   pediatric scope. She had been electively intubated prior to the
   procedure and was extubated post ERCP. Post proceedure, she was
   ordered125ml/hr NS; she likely received 400cc LR during the procedure.
   She then developed respiratory distress with respiratory rates in 40's,
   no documented hypoxia.  She was then reintubated in the PACU. She was
   given lasix 20mg IV in the PACU. She was transfered to the floor on AC
   500x 14, FI02 50%, PEEP 5.
   .
   ROS: unable to obtain

   .

   nearby, she is a former smoker of less than one pack per day, she
   drinks wine occaisonally
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of gastric cancer, who underwent partial proximal gastrectomy and pylorplasty with J-tube placement. She was admitted to the hospital after intubation for respiratory distress, which has been a recurring issue throughout her hospital stay. She has undergone multiple procedures, including esophageal stenting, and has been treated with various medications, including antibiotics and antifungals.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Respiratory distress, which has led to repeated intubations
* Anastomotic leak, which was detected on a gastrografin swallow and has been treated with esophageal stenting
* S/p gastrectomy, which has resulted in a J-tube and tube feeds
* Hypertension, which is being managed with medications
* Possible diastolic dysfunction, which is being evaluated with an echo

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's repeated intubations and respiratory distress may lead to respiratory failure if not managed properly.
* Anastomotic leak: The patient's anastomotic leak may lead to further complications, such as peritonitis or sepsis, if not treated promptly and effectively.
* Sepsis: The patient's recent surgeries and procedures may increase her risk of developing sepsis, particularly if she develops an infection.
* Diastolic dysfunction: The patient's possible diastolic dysfunction may lead to heart failure if not managed properly.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's gastric cancer and recent gastrectomy may increase her risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, particularly if the anastomotic leak is not managed properly.
* Pneumonia: The patient's repeated intubations and respiratory distress may increase her risk of developing pneumonia.

Given the patient's complex medical condition and potential complications, it is essential to continue to monitor her closely and adjust her treatment plan as needed to prevent or manage any potential complications that may arise.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old woman who was admitted to the ICU after undergoing ERCP procedure for stent placement. She developed acute respiratory distress post-extubation and was reintubated in the PACU. The patient is currently sedated and intubated, and is receiving mechanical ventilation. She has a history of complicated GI issues and anemia. The patient's vital signs are stable, but she has evidence of volume overload, with a high respiratory rate and crackles on examination. Her ECG shows T-wave inversions, which are new, and her labs show elevated cardiac enzymes. She has a history of hypertension, and her blood pressure is currently elevated. The patient is receiving prophylactic antibiotics, and her wound is being managed with a JP drain.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory distress and reintubation in the PACU put her at risk for respiratory failure. Close monitoring of her respiratory status and consideration of non-invasive ventilation or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) may be necessary.
2. Volume overload: The patient's high fluid intake and evidence of volume overload on examination put her at risk for pulmonary edema, cardiac failure, and increased risk of respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's ECG changes and elevated cardiac enzymes suggest cardiac decompression. Close monitoring of her cardiac status and consideration of cardiology consultation may be necessary.
4. Wound complications: The patient's wound is at risk for infection, dehiscence, and bleeding. Close monitoring of her wound and consideration of surgical consultation may be necessary.
5. Hypertensive crisis: The patient's elevated blood pressure and history of hypertension put her at risk for hypertensive crisis. Close monitoring of her blood pressure and consideration of antihypertensive medication may be necessary.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may exacerbate her respiratory and cardiac status. Close monitoring of her anemia and consideration of blood transfusion may be necessary.
7. Sepsis: The patient's history of complicated GI issues and elevated cardiac enzymes put her at risk for sepsis. Close monitoring of her vital signs and consideration of sepsis protocols may be necessary.

Summary:

The patient, a 74-year-old female, is a post-operative gastric cancer patient who was transferred to the ICU for respiratory stress after an esophageal stenting procedure. She was intubated and is currently on mechanical ventilation. Her recent 24-hour events include a resolution of TWI on EKG, negative cardiac enzymes, and restarted home dose of Diovan. She has been receiving labetalol and Lasix for hypertension and fluid management. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 78 bpm, and blood pressure of 132/66 mmHg. Her respiratory support includes CPAP/PSV ventilation with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Edema: The patient is at risk of developing pulmonary edema post-extubation, which can lead to respiratory failure and further complications.
2. Anastamotic Leak: The patient has a history of anastamotic leak, which can lead to sepsis and further complications if not managed properly.
3. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may not be fully controlled, which can increase the risk of cardiovascular complications.
4. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's recent gastrectomy and J-tube placement may increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or obstruction.
5. Infection: The patient's central line and J-tube placement may increase the risk of infection, particularly bloodstream infections.
6. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may not be fully resolved, and she may require further respiratory support or mechanical ventilation.
7. Cardiac Complications: The patient's cardiac enzymes are negative, but she may still be at risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or myocardial infarction.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's plan includes extubation, nitroglycerin drip peri-extubation, Lasix prior to extubation, nebs, and trend fever curve and WBC counts. She will also require continued cefepime and fluconazole for anastamotic leak, and a surgery consult for further evaluation and management. Her J-tube and tube feeds will need to be monitored and adjusted as necessary.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female admitted to the ICU for respiratory distress and suspected anastamotic leak following gastric cancer resection and esophageal stenting. The patient has been intubated and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 78 bpm, blood pressure of 132/66 mmHg, and a respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 95% on 40% FiO2.

The patient's laboratory results show mild leukocytosis and low-grade fevers, which may indicate an underlying infectious process. The patient's chest X-ray is still very wet, suggesting ongoing fluid overload.

The patient's medical conditions include hypertension, hyperglycemia, and anastamotic leak. The patient is receiving prophylactic antibiotics and antifungal medication.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Weaning of propofol and fentanyl to assess for extubation readiness.
2. Further diuresis to manage fluid overload.
3. Repeat chest X-ray to assess for resolution of fluid overload.
4. Echocardiogram to evaluate for diastolic dysfunction.
5. Repeat EKG to assess for resolution of transient ST segment elevation.
6. Fentanyl boluses for pain management while intubated.
7. Transition to oral pain medication upon extubation.
8. Continued monitoring of fever curve and white blood cell count.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure due to ongoing fluid overload and anastamotic leak.
2. Sepsis or septic shock due to underlying infectious process.
3. Cardiac complications, such as diastolic dysfunction, due to fluid overload.
4. Gastrointestinal complications, such as anastamotic leak or perforation.
5. Wound complications, such as infection or dehiscence, due to surgical site.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the plan of care accordingly to prevent these potential complications and ensure optimal patient outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with acute respiratory failure post-extubation in the PACU. The patient was reintubated due to respiratory distress and has a history of flash pulmonary edema secondary to poorly controlled hypertension. The patient's cardiac enzymes do not suggest an ischemic event, but rather probable demand ischemia.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7°C (99.9°F), heart rate of 77 beats per minute (bpm), and blood pressure of 132/66 mmHg. The patient's respiratory rate is 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 94% on 40% FiO2. The patient's ABG results show a pH of 7.44, pCO2 of 46 mmHg, and pO2 of 98 mmHg.

The patient's physical examination reveals a well-nourished individual with no signs of distress. The patient's lungs are clear, and the chest is soft and non-tender. The patient's extremities are edema-free, and the skin is not assessed.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 12.6-12.9 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.4-9.5 g/dL, and platelet count of 446-464 K/uL. The patient's cardiac enzymes are within normal limits, and the troponin-T level is 0.02 ng/mL.

The patient's plan includes administration of Lasix to reduce fluid overload, IV TNG to decrease preload, and extubation this morning. The patient will also continue to receive cefipime and fluconazole for anastomotic leak prophylaxis.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure can worsen if not managed properly, leading to hypoxia, hypercapnia, and respiratory acidosis.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of flash pulmonary edema and probable demand ischemia can increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction, cardiac arrhythmias, and cardiogenic shock.
3. Infection: The patient's anastomotic leak and respiratory failure can increase the risk of infection, particularly pneumonia and sepsis.
4. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid overload can worsen if not managed properly, leading to hypervolemia, hypertension, and cardiac complications.
5. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's nutrition via J-tube can lead to malnutrition and electrolyte imbalances if not managed properly.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications and ensure optimal care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of gastric cancer, who underwent resection and esophageal stenting. She was transferred to the ICU for respiratory stress and was successfully extubated yesterday. She is currently receiving tube feeds and has a J-tube in place.

The patient is complaining of significant nausea, which improved with zofran and compazine. She has a history of allergies to adhesive tape, Percocet, and itching.

Vital signs are within normal limits, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 88 bpm, blood pressure of 134/59 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute. Her oxygen saturation is 98% on nasal cannula.

The patient has a history of respiratory failure, anastamotic leak, and hypertension. She is at risk for pulmonary edema post-extubation and will need to be closely monitored.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 12.1, hemoglobin of 9.9 g/dL, and platelet count of 464. Her electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with a slight elevation in troponin-T.

The patient's physical examination reveals a soft abdomen with hypoactive bowel sounds, a midline healing incision with slight erythema but no edema or drainage, and JP in place with minimal serosanguinous fluid.

The patient's plan includes:

* Monitoring for pulmonary edema post-extubation
* Administration of nitroglycerin drip peri-extubation
* Use of lasix prior to extubation
* Nebulization therapy
* Trend fever curve and WBC counts
* Continued cefepime and fluconazole for anastamotic leak
* Surgery consult for anastamotic leak
* F/u GI and surgery recs
* Transition from fentanyl boluses to percocet and dilauded for pain management
* Cont. metoprolol and diovan for hypertension

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Pulmonary edema post-extubation
* Anastamotic leak with potential for peritonitis or abscess formation
* Respiratory failure requiring re-intubation
* Hypertension requiring adjustment of medication regimen
* Nausea and vomiting requiring adjustment of medication regimen
* Electrolyte imbalance requiring adjustment of medication regimen
* Wound infection or dehiscence requiring surgical intervention.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old female with a recently diagnosed gastric cancer, who underwent resection and esophageal stenting. She was transferred to the ICU from another hospital due to respiratory stress and was intubated. The patient was successfully extubated yesterday and is currently on nasal cannula oxygen at 3L with a saturation of 98%. She is complaining of nausea, but her pain is under control. Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 88 bpm, and blood pressure of 134/59 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 25 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 98%. Her physical examination is unremarkable, except for a midline healing incision with slight erythema.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Anastamotic leak: The patient is at risk for anastamotic leak, which can lead to peritonitis, sepsis, and potentially life-threatening complications. Close monitoring of the patient's clinical condition and laboratory results is essential to detect any signs of leak or infection.
2. Respiratory distress: Although the patient was successfully extubated, she is still at risk for respiratory distress due to her underlying lung disease and the risk of pneumonia. Monitoring her oxygen saturation and respiratory rate is crucial to detect any signs of respiratory compromise.
3. Nausea and vomiting: The patient's nausea and vomiting may be a sign of gastrointestinal dysfunction or a side effect of medication. Close monitoring of her hydration status and electrolyte levels is essential to prevent dehydration and electrolyte imbalance.
4. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is slightly low, which may be a sign of hypovolemia or vasodilation. Monitoring her blood pressure and fluid status is essential to detect any signs of hypotension or fluid overload.
5. Diastolic dysfunction: The patient's echocardiogram may show signs of diastolic dysfunction, which can lead to heart failure and pulmonary edema. Close monitoring of her cardiac function and fluid status is essential to detect any signs of diastolic dysfunction.
6. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to her underlying disease and the risk of surgical site infection. Monitoring her laboratory results and clinical condition is essential to detect any signs of infection.
7. Bleeding: The patient's platelet count is slightly low, which may be a sign of bleeding or platelet dysfunction. Close monitoring of her bleeding status and platelet count is essential to detect any signs of bleeding or platelet dysfunction.

Overall, the patient is at risk for various medical complications, and close monitoring of her clinical condition and laboratory results is essential to detect any signs of complications and provide appropriate treatment.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of gastric cancer, who underwent resection and is currently admitted to the ICU for respiratory stress after intubation. The patient was extubated without complications and is currently receiving tube feeds and pain management with fentanyl and morphine.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 88 bpm, and blood pressure of 134/59 mmHg. The patient's respiratory support includes a nasal cannula with 40% FiO2 and a PSV/SBT ventilator mode.

The patient's physical examination reveals a soft and non-tender abdomen with hypoactive bowel sounds and a midline healing incision with slight erythema but no edema or drainage. The patient's extremities have no signs of edema or cyanosis.

The patient's laboratory results show normal white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, with a slightly elevated creatinine level. The patient's troponin-T level is normal, and the differential neutrophil count shows a normal distribution.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Pulmonary edema post-extubation: The patient is at risk for developing pulmonary edema due to the recent respiratory stress and the possibility of fluid overload.
2. Anastamotic leak: The patient has undergone gastric resection and is at risk for developing anastamotic leak, which could lead to complications such as peritonitis and sepsis.
3. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for developing sepsis due to the recent surgical procedure and the possibility of surgical site infection.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk for developing respiratory failure due to the recent respiratory stress and the possibility of fluid overload.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient is at risk for developing gastrointestinal bleeding due to the recent surgical procedure and the possibility of anastamotic leak.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and ensure optimal care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female who has recently undergone gastric cancer resection and is currently admitted to the ICU after intubation for respiratory stress. The patient has been extubated and is doing well, with some nausea, for which she has been prescribed Zofran and Compazine. She has been receiving various medications, including Lasix, Labetalol, Pantoprazole, Morphine Sulfate, and Heparin Sodium.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 88 beats per minute, blood pressure of 134/59 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute. Her oxygen saturation is 98% on nasal cannula.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 12.1-13.0 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.9 g/dL
* Platelet count: 464-479 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.0-1.1 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.02 ng/mL
* Calcium: 8.3 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.1 mg/dL

The patient has several potential medical complications that may arise, including:

* Pulmonary edema post-extubation
* Anastamotic leak
* Sepsis
* Respiratory failure
* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Deep vein thrombosis

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Monitoring for pulmonary edema post-extubation
* Continuing antibiotics and antifungal therapy for anastamotic leak
* Surgery consult for anastamotic leak
* Fentanyl boluses for pain while intubated, transitioning back to Percocet and Dilaudid
* Tube feeds and J-tube management
* Monitoring for hypertension and adjusting medications as necessary
* Prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis and stress ulcer prevention
* Stress ulcer prevention with PPI
* VAP prevention with HOB elevation, mouth care, and daily wake-up
* Need for restraints reviewed
* Family meeting held and ICU consent signed

The patient's code status is full code, and her disposition is ICU.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-inch tall, 68 kg (admission: 65 kg) female who was admitted to the ICU postoperatively due to respiratory failure. She was intubated and mechanically ventilated, but was extubated yesterday following diuresis. She is currently extubated and receiving oxygen therapy via nasal cannula. Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.1°C, heart rate of 82 bpm, and blood pressure of 153/79 mmHg. She is receiving various medications, including antibiotics, antifungals, and pain management medications.

The patient's laboratory results show mild anemia, elevated white blood cell count, and elevated troponin levels. Her electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated potassium level. Her arterial blood gas (ABG) results show a pH of 7.26, PCO2 of 26 mmHg, and PO2 of 96 mmHg.

Physical examination reveals a well-nourished patient with no signs of respiratory distress. Her cardiovascular examination is normal, and she has no signs of peripheral edema.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory failure and need for oxygen therapy via nasal cannula make her susceptible to pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and elevated troponin levels suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could be exacerbated by her underlying respiratory failure.
3. Hypertension: The patient's poorly controlled hypertension could lead to further complications, such as cardiac damage or stroke.
4. Anastomotic leak: The patient's ongoing antibiotics and fluconazole treatment suggest that there may be an anastomotic leak, which could lead to further complications if not managed properly.
5. DVT: The patient's prophylactic treatment with SQ UF heparin suggests that there may be a risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
6. VAP: The patient's need for oxygen therapy via nasal cannula makes her susceptible to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Recommendations:

1. Continue close monitoring of the patient's vital signs and laboratory results to detect any signs of worsening respiratory failure or sepsis.
2. Consider adjusting the patient's antibiotic regimen to address the possibility of sepsis.
3. Continue to manage the patient's hypertension with medication and close monitoring.
4. Consult with the patient's surgeons to determine the best course of action for managing the anastomotic leak and potential complications.
5. Continue prophylactic treatment with SQ UF heparin to reduce the risk of DVT.
6. Consider switching to a different oxygen therapy device if the nasal cannula is not providing adequate oxygenation.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 65-year-old female who was transferred to the ICU after a cardiac arrest, reportedly in ventricular fibrillation (vfib), and was resuscitated and intubated. The patient has a history of underlying coronary artery disease (CAD) and has been on fluconazole, which may have contributed to her cardiac arrest.

The patient's current condition is critical, with ongoing hypotension, respiratory failure, and bleeding. The note mentions that the patient's hemoglobin (Hct) is dropping, and abdominal examination shows increased distension, with the patient grimacing to palpation in the left upper quadrant. The patient is at risk for torsades de pointes due to her electrolyte abnormalities and the use of fluconazole.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hypokalemia (K+: 2.1 mmol/L)
* Hypophosphatemia (PO4: 1.2 mg/dL)
* Anemia (Hct: 19.8%)
* Elevated troponin-T (0.03 ng/mL)
* Elevated lactate acid (3.0 mmol/L)
* Elevated LDH (429 IU/L)

The patient's radiology results show:

* Chest X-ray (CXR) shows a right internal jugular (IJ) line in the superior vena cava/right ventricular junction, with no pneumothorax.

The patient's medical plan includes:

* Aggressive volume resuscitation with IV normal saline and blood
* Stat CT neck/chest/abdomen when hemodynamically stable
* Possibility of surgery for abdominal bleeding
* ICU care, including nutrition, glycemic control, lines, prophylaxis, and VAP prevention

The patient's code status is full code, and she is currently in the ICU.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of gastric cancer, who underwent resection and esophageal stenting. She was initially admitted to the hospital for respiratory distress due to pulmonary edema, and was later readmitted after a pulseless VT/VF arrest.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 36.7°C, HR 109 bpm, BP 109/62 mmHg, RR 18 breaths/min, SpO2 96%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient has been receiving vasopressors and inotropes to maintain blood pressure and cardiac output.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received a total of 6,260 mL of fluids over the past 24 hours, with a net balance of 5,693 mL.
* Respiratory support: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest and is at risk for ischemic events. She is receiving cardiac monitoring and anticoagulation therapy.
* Abdominal status: The patient has a splenic hematoma and is at risk for bleeding. She is receiving blood products and platelet transfusions as needed.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, but she is at risk for respiratory failure due to her underlying pulmonary disease and the need for prolonged mechanical ventilation.
* Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest and is at risk for ischemic events. She is receiving cardiac monitoring and anticoagulation therapy, but she may require further cardiac interventions or medications to manage her cardiac status.
* Bleeding complications: The patient has a splenic hematoma and is at risk for bleeding. She is receiving blood products and platelet transfusions as needed, but she may require further interventions or medications to manage her bleeding risk.
* Infection: The patient has a history of sepsis and is at risk for infection. She is receiving antibiotics and antifungal therapy, but she may require further interventions or medications to manage her infection risk.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of gastric cancer and is at risk for gastrointestinal complications such as bleeding, obstruction, or perforation. She is receiving tube feeds and pain medications, but she may require further interventions or medications to manage her gastrointestinal symptoms.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications and promote recovery.

   Assessment and Plan
   74 year old female with recently diagnosed gastric CA, s/p resection
   transferred from [**Hospital3 4838**] for esophageal stenting, initially
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for respiratory failure [**2-13**] pulmonary edema, then
   extubated and called out to medical floor.  Readmitted to MICU s/p
   pulseless VT/VF arrest, then diagnosed with splenic laceration
   requiring massive transfusion and splenic artery embolization.
   .
   # Splenic artery laceration: s/p embolization by IR with recently
   stable Hcts. Patient had known old splenic laceration, but reason for
   re-bleed is unclear.  It is possible that the bleeding was exacerbated
   by CPR, but the patient had abdominal pain prior to her arrest,
   suggesting that the bleed could have begun before the arrest.
   -- f/u IR and surgery recommendations
   -- Check Hct Q4H
   -- Monitor vitals closely
   -- Transfuse for any drop in Hct
   -- Maintain active T+S with multiple units crossed
   .
   # s/p cardiac arrest -- now with return to sinus rhythm. No known
   cardiac history but echo with LV systolic dysfunction c/w CAD, so there
   is concern for an ischemic event as an etiology.
   -- Repeat EKG this a.m.
   -- Repeat echo
   -- Cycle enzymes
   -- f/u cardiology recs
   -- holding ASA in the setting of recent massive bleeding
   -- holding metoprolol in the setting of recent massive bleeding
   -- maintain K>4, Mg>2
   .
   # Pericardial effusion: Found on CT chest. Patient is s/p CPR.
   -- echocardiogram to further characterize and evaluate hemodynamic
   significance.
   .
   # Mechanical ventilation/Airway protection: Pt has now been intubated 5
   times (1) hematemasis 2) respiratory distress 3) for ERCP 4)respiratory
   distress following extubation 5) code blue/cardiac arrest with feeble
   respirations. Currently the patient is at high risk of aspiration given
   secretions in esophagus and requires airway protection.
   -- Most recent ABG shows good oxygenation and ventilation. Continue
   current vent settings
   .
   # Probable CAD
   [**Hospital **] medical management with statin.
   -- Hold ASA, BB, and [**Last Name (un) 284**] as above
   -- f/u cards c/s
   -- cycle enyzmes as above
   -- serial EKGs
   -- repeat echo as above
   .
   # CHF: No role for diuresis in setting of recent massive bleeding.
   .
   # Tachycardia: DDx includes hypovolemia ([**2-13**] hemorrhage), pain, sepsis.
   -- pull central venous line placed at outside hospital
   -- treat pain adequately
   -- low threshold for blood transfusion
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Likely [**2-13**] hypoperfusion in the setting of
   cardiac arrest and hemorrhage from splenic lac.
   -- monitor urine output and BP
   -- maintain renal perfusion
   .
   # Anastamotic leak: s/p stenting. Prior to the patient
s recent
   bleeding, the plan was for the patient to remain NPO, with feeds via
   J-tube. Currently patient has massively distended abdomen and fluid in
   esophagus.
   -- d/c antibiotics
   -- hold TFs given massive abdominal distending and fluid in esophagus
   .
   # S/p gastrectomy:
   -- holding tube feeds
   -- Pain meds prn
   -- f/u surgery recs
   .
   # Benign HTN:
   -- holding metoprolol and diovan
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: holding tube feeds, replete lytes aggressively to maintain
   K>4.0, Mg>2.0
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:  Femoral line placed during code + new IJ; femoral line will
   need to be d/c
   Will need to place peripherals.
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: heparin SC
   Stress ulcer: pantoprazole
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: family
   Code status: DNR
   Disposition: ICU

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and pulmonary edema. She had a recent diagnosis of gastric cancer and underwent esophageal stenting. She was extubated and transferred to the medical floor, but was readmitted to the ICU after a pulseless VT/VF arrest, which was diagnosed as a splenic laceration requiring massive transfusion and splenic artery embolization.

The patient has undergone several interventions, including CPR, splenic artery embolization, and intubation. She has a history of cardiac arrest, and an echocardiogram revealed LV systolic dysfunction and CAD. She also has a pericardial effusion, which is being evaluated.

The patient is currently being treated for several conditions, including:

* Splenic laceration with ongoing bleeding
* Cardiac arrest with LV systolic dysfunction and CAD
* Pericardial effusion
* Mechanical ventilation/Airway protection
* Probable CAD
* CHF
* Tachycardia
* Acute renal failure
* Anastamotic leak
* S/p gastrectomy
* Benign HTN

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Continued bleeding from the splenic laceration
2. Cardiac complications, including arrhythmias and cardiogenic shock
3. Pericardial tamponade
4. Respiratory failure
5. Acute kidney injury
6. Anastamotic leak and potential peritonitis
7. Sepsis
8. Pulmonary embolism
9. Deep vein thrombosis
10. Ventilator-associated pneumonia

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and lab values closely
2. Administer blood products as needed to maintain hemodynamic stability
3. Consider repeat echocardiogram to evaluate cardiac function
4. Continue mechanical ventilation and airway protection
5. Monitor for signs of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias and cardiogenic shock
6. Consider antibiotics for suspected anastamotic leak and potential peritonitis
7. Monitor for signs of sepsis and initiate treatment if necessary
8. Consider prophylactic anticoagulation to prevent deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism
9. Monitor for signs of ventilator-associated pneumonia and initiate treatment if necessary.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female who has recently been diagnosed with gastric cancer and underwent resection. She was initially admitted to the hospital for respiratory failure and pulmonary edema, but was later transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further management.

The patient has had a significant number of complications, including:

1. Cardiac arrest: The patient experienced a pulseless VT/VF arrest, which was treated with cardioversion and resuscitation. She was diagnosed with splenic laceration and required massive transfusion and splenic artery embolization.
2. Splenic laceration: The patient had a known old splenic laceration, but the recent bleeding was likely exacerbated by CPR. The patient's hemoglobin (Hct) levels have been declining, and she has received multiple units of blood.
3. Cardiac dysfunction: The patient has evidence of left ventricular systolic dysfunction on echocardiogram, which is consistent with coronary artery disease (CAD).
4. Pericardial effusion: A computed tomography (CT) scan revealed a pericardial effusion, which may be contributing to the patient's cardiac dysfunction.
5. Mechanical ventilation: The patient has been intubated multiple times due to respiratory distress, hematemesis, and cardiac arrest. She is currently at high risk of aspiration and requires airway protection.
6. Probable CAD: The patient has a history of CAD, which is likely contributing to her cardiac dysfunction.
7. CHF: The patient has evidence of congestive heart failure (CHF), which is likely due to her cardiac dysfunction.
8. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia may be due to hypovolemia, pain, or sepsis.
9. Anastamotic leak: The patient has a history of gastrectomy and anastamotic leak, which may be contributing to her abdominal distension and fluid in the esophagus.
10. Benign HTN: The patient has a history of hypertension, which is being managed with medications.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin (Hct) levels have been declining, with a current level of 19.8%.
* Platelet count is low, with a current level of 8.
* White blood cell count is elevated, with a current level of 17.2.
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels are elevated, indicating kidney dysfunction.
* Electrolyte levels are abnormal, with potassium and magnesium levels being low.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Close monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results.
2. Transfusion of blood products as needed to maintain Hct levels.
3. Maintenance of active transfusion service with multiple units crossed.
4. Holding of medications, including aspirin, metoprolol, and diovan, due to recent massive bleeding.
5. Repeat echocardiogram and cardiac enzymes to evaluate cardiac function.
6. Serial electrocardiograms to monitor for cardiac arrhythmias.
7. Repeat CT scan to evaluate for pericardial effusion and other complications.
8. Continued mechanical ventilation and airway protection.
9. Management of abdominal distension and fluid in the esophagus.
10. F/u with cardiology and surgery services.

The patient's code status is do not resuscitate (DNR).

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual who has been admitted to the ICU due to hypotension and intra-abdominal hemorrhage. The patient has undergone embolization of the splenic artery by interventional radiology, and serial hemoglobin checks this morning have been stable.

The patient is currently intubated and sedated, and is receiving respiratory support. They have acute renal failure secondary to massive abdominal hemorrhage, hypotension, and poor renal perfusion. The patient has made urine this morning following aggressive volume resuscitation with blood products and IV normal saline.

The patient has also experienced cardiac arrest, which was triggered by acute hemorrhage and possible ischemia. Cardiac enzymes have been flat, and ASA is currently on hold. The patient remains critically ill and is at risk for further complications.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Continued bleeding: The patient's splenic artery has been embolized, but there is still a risk of continued bleeding, which could lead to further hypotension and hypovolemic shock.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen if they do not receive adequate fluid resuscitation and support.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and possible ischemia may lead to further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if they do not receive adequate oxygenation and ventilation support.
5. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis may be stress-related, but there is still a risk of infection, particularly in the setting of invasive lines and procedures.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient's bleeding may be exacerbated by coagulopathy, which could lead to further hemorrhage and bleeding complications.
7. Organ failure: The patient's multiple organ dysfunction may worsen if they do not receive adequate support and treatment.

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and to adjust their treatment plan accordingly to prevent further complications and improve their outcome.

   Assessment and Plan
   74 year old female with recently diagnosed gastric CA, s/p resection,
   transferred from [**Hospital3 4838**] for esophageal stenting, initially
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for respiratory failure [**2-13**] pulmonary edema, then
   extubated and called out to medical floor.  Readmitted to MICU s/p
   pulseless VT/VF arrest, then diagnosed with splenic laceration
   requiring massive transfusion and splenic artery embolization.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Pt has now been intubated 5 times (1)
   hematemasis 2) respiratory distress 3) for ERCP 4)respiratory distress
   following extubation 5) code blue/cardiac arrest with feeble
   respirations. Currently, the patient appears to be volume-overloaded
   and would likely not tolerate extubation without further diruesis.
   -- Diurese with goal net negative 1L today
   -- Continue mechanical ventilation
   .
   # Splenic artery laceration s/p embolization by IR: Hct generally
   stable although slowly trending down.
   -- f/u IR and surgery recommendations
   -- Check Hct Q6H
   -- Transfuse for Hct<30
   -- Maintain active T+S with multiple units crossed
   -- Consider repeat tagged RBC scan if Hct continues to trend down
   .
   # s/p cardiac arrest/probable CAD -- No known cardiac history but echo
   with LV systolic dysfunction c/w CAD, so there is concern for an
   ischemic event as an etiology.
   -- Monitor on telemetry: frequent ectopy but no other events
   -- Cardiac enzymes unchanged
   -- f/u cardiology recs
   -- holding ASA, [**Last Name (un) 284**] in the setting of recent massive bleeding
   -- restart metoprolol
   -- continue atorvastatin
   -- maintain K>4, Mg>2
   .
   # Pericardial effusion: Found on CT chest. Patient is s/p CPR.
   -- Echocardiogram shows fat pad but not effusion
   .
   # CHF: Volume overload
   -- Diurese slowly with goal net negative 1 L today
   .
   # Leukocytosis: WBC up to 22.2.  Could be reaction to acute stress of
   bleed, but also concerning for infection. Have already pulled femoral
   line placed during code.
   -- pan culture
   -- check differential
 shows 88 neutrophils and 5 bands
   -- continue antibiotics (cefepime and fluconazole), consider adding
   gram positive coverage pending culture results
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Differential diagnosis includes ATN,
   obstruction, intraabdominal compartment syndrome.
   -- monitor urine output
   -- maintain renal perfusion
   -- check bladder pressure
   -- renal U/S
   .
   # s/p gastrectomy complicated by anastamotic leak s/p stenting:
   Followed by surgery and GI
   -- restart tube feeding via J-tube
   -- f/u GI and surgery recs
   -- pain meds PRN
   .
   # HTN:
   -- restart metoprolol
   -- holding Diovan in setting of ARF and recent bleeding
   .
   # h/o breast CA
   -- continue Arimidex
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: restart tube feeds, replete lytes aggressively to maintain
   K>4.0, Mg>2.0
   Glycemic Control: insulin SC
   Lines:
   Interval jugular CVL
   Will attempt to place peripherals
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: pneumoboots
   Stress ulcer: pantoprazole
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: family
   Code status: DNR
   Disposition: ICU

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old female admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure, pulmonary edema, and splenic laceration requiring massive transfusion and splenic artery embolization. She has a history of recently diagnosed gastric cancer, s/p resection, and esophageal stenting. The patient has been intubated five times due to various respiratory issues and has experienced a pulseless VT/VF arrest, which led to the diagnosis of splenic laceration.

The patient is currently receiving mechanical ventilation, diuretics, and antibiotics. She has a pericardial effusion, leukocytosis, and acute renal failure, with a differential diagnosis including ATN, obstruction, and intraabdominal compartment syndrome. The patient is also at risk for cardiac ischemia due to probable CAD.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and she is at risk for further respiratory distress.
2. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and positive blood cultures may indicate an infection, which could lead to sepsis.
3. Cardiac ischemia: The patient's probable CAD and recent cardiac arrest put her at risk for cardiac ischemia.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to chronic kidney disease if not managed properly.
5. Intraabdominal compartment syndrome: The patient's splenic laceration and recent bleeding may lead to intraabdominal compartment syndrome, which could worsen her respiratory and cardiac status.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's recent gastrectomy and anastomotic leak may lead to further gastrointestinal complications, such as bowel obstruction or perforation.
7. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's recent cardiac arrest and ongoing bleeding may lead to hemodynamic instability, which could worsen her respiratory and cardiac status.

Plan:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and diuretics to manage respiratory failure and volume overload.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely, including frequent echocardiograms and cardiac enzymes.
3. Manage the patient's leukocytosis with antibiotics and consider adding gram-positive coverage pending culture results.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and consider renal ultrasound and bladder pressure monitoring.
5. Manage the patient's pain and glycemic control with insulin SC.
6. Consider repeat tagged RBC scan if the patient's Hct continues to trend down.
7. F/u IR and surgery recommendations for the splenic laceration and anastomotic leak.
8. Restart metoprolol and continue atorvastatin.
9. Monitor the patient's potassium and magnesium levels closely and replete as necessary.
10. Consider placing peripheral lines and attempt to place a jugular CVL.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 74-year-old female, was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure, pulmonary edema, and cardiac arrest. She had a recent diagnosis of gastric cancer, underwent resection, and was transferred to the ICU for esophageal stenting. She experienced a pulseless VT/VF arrest and was diagnosed with a splenic laceration requiring massive transfusion and splenic artery embolization.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Tachycardic, hypotensive, and tachypneic
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Central venous pressure (CVP) and pulmonary artery catheter (PAC) monitoring
* Fluid balance: Total fluid input of 5,534 mL, with a balance of 5,035 mL
* Respiratory support: Intubated, receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%
* Cardiovascular status: Sinus tachycardia, with a concern for ischemic event as an etiology of cardiac arrest
* Abdominal status: Markedly distended, with a tense abdomen, and a midline incision with a drain in place
* Laboratory results: Elevated white blood cell count, elevated troponin-T, and elevated lactate acid

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Splenic artery laceration: Rebleeding, bleeding complications, and potential need for further embolization or surgery
2. Cardiac arrest: Ischemic event, arrhythmias, and potential need for further cardiac evaluation and management
3. Pericardial effusion: Hemodynamic compromise, cardiac tamponade, and potential need for pericardiocentesis or surgery
4. Mechanical ventilation/Airway protection: Aspiration, respiratory failure, and potential need for further airway management
5. Probable CAD: Ischemic event, cardiac arrhythmias, and potential need for further cardiac evaluation and management
6. CHF: Fluid overload, cardiac failure, and potential need for diuretic therapy
7. Tachycardia: Hypovolemia, pain, sepsis, and potential need for fluid resuscitation, pain management, and antibiotic therapy
8. Acute renal failure: Hypoperfusion, acute kidney injury, and potential need for renal replacement therapy
9. Anastamotic leak: Abdominal distension, fluid accumulation, and potential need for further surgical intervention
10. S/p gastrectomy: Delayed gastric emptying, abdominal distension, and potential need for further surgical intervention

The patient requires close monitoring and management of her various medical conditions, including cardiac arrest, splenic laceration, and pericardial effusion. Further evaluation and management of her cardiac status, including echocardiogram and cardiac enzymes, are also necessary.

   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for respiratory failure [**2-13**] pulmonary edema, then
   extubated and called out to medical floor.  Readmitted to MICU s/p

   requiring massive transfusion and splenic artery embolization.
   .
   # Splenic artery laceration: s/p embolization by IR with recently
   stable Hcts. Patient had known old splenic laceration, but reason for
   re-bleed is unclear.  It is possible that the bleeding was exacerbated
   by CPR, but the patient had abdominal pain prior to her arrest,
   suggesting that the bleed could have begun before the arrest.
   -- f/u IR and surgery recommendations
   -- Check Hct Q4H
   -- Monitor vitals closely
   -- Transfuse for any drop in Hct
   -- Maintain active T+S with multiple units crossed
   .
   # s/p cardiac arrest -- now with return to sinus rhythm. No known
   cardiac history but echo with LV systolic dysfunction c/w CAD, so there
   is concern for an ischemic event as an etiology.
   -- Repeat EKG this a.m.
   -- Repeat echo
   -- Cycle enzymes
   -- f/u cardiology recs
   -- holding ASA in the setting of recent massive bleeding
   -- holding metoprolol in the setting of recent massive bleeding
   -- maintain K>4, Mg>2
   .
   # Pericardial effusion: Found on CT chest. Patient is s/p CPR.
   -- echocardiogram to further characterize and evaluate hemodynamic
   significance.
   .
   # Mechanical ventilation/Airway protection: Pt has now been intubated 5
   times (1) hematemasis 2) respiratory distress 3) for ERCP 4)respiratory
   distress following extubation 5) code blue/cardiac arrest with feeble
   respirations. Currently the patient is at high risk of aspiration given
   secretions in esophagus and requires airway protection.
   -- Most recent ABG shows good oxygenation and ventilation. Continue
   current vent settings

   [**Hospital **] medical management with statin.

   -- treat pain adequately

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 74-year-old female, was admitted to the ICU after a pulseless VT/VF arrest, diagnosed with splenic laceration requiring massive transfusion and splenic artery embolization. She had a known old splenic laceration, but the reason for the re-bleed is unclear. The patient has been intubated five times due to various reasons, including hematemesis, respiratory distress, and cardiac arrest. She is currently on mechanical ventilation and requires airway protection.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.6°C (99.6°F)
* Heart rate: 102 bpm (101-134 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 129/68 mmHg (90-151/86 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 17 inspirations per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 97%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 10.8 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 34%
* Platelet count: 224,000/μL
* White blood cell count: 17.6 × 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.03 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 1.8 mmol/L

The patient has several potential medical complications, including:

1. Splenic artery laceration: The patient has a splenic laceration that required embolization, and there is a risk of re-bleeding.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient had a pulseless VT/VF arrest, and there is concern for an ischemic event as an etiology.
3. Pericardial effusion: The patient has a pericardial effusion, which may be causing cardiac tamponade.
4. Mechanical ventilation/Airway protection: The patient requires airway protection due to secretions in the esophagus.
5. Acute renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure, likely due to hypoperfusion in the setting of cardiac arrest and hemorrhage.
6. Anastamotic leak: The patient has a potential anastamotic leak, which may be causing abdominal distension and fluid in the esophagus.
7. Benign hypertension: The patient has benign hypertension, which may be contributing to her tachycardia.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results
* Maintenance of active transfusion with multiple units crossed
* Treatment of pain adequately
* Low threshold for blood transfusion
* Monitoring of urine output and blood pressure
* Maintenance of renal perfusion
* Holding of antibiotics and tube feeds
* Repletion of electrolytes aggressively to maintain K>4.0 and Mg>2.0
* Placement of peripherals and d/c of femoral line
* Prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure and splenic hemorrhage. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 102 bpm, blood pressure of 127/67 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 96%.

The patient has undergone blood transfusions and is receiving infusions of midazolam and fentanyl. The patient's laboratory results indicate anemia, acute, secondary to blood loss, with a hemoglobin level of 10.8 g/dL. The patient's white blood cell count is elevated at 17.6 K/uL, and the platelet count is 224 K/uL.

The patient has multiple medical complications, including:

1. Anemia, acute, secondary to blood loss (hemorrhage, bleeding): The patient has a splenic hemorrhage and has received blood transfusions.
2. Hypovolemia (volume depletion - without shock): The patient has been intravascularly volume repleted with blood products.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient has PVCs on the monitor and is receiving electrolytes and repletion as needed.
4. Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS): The patient has a component of volume overload and is being diuresed.
5. Congestive heart failure: The patient's cardiac function is limited, making it difficult to wean off the ventilator.
6. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, which may be stress-related or indicative of infection.
7. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is increased, likely due to ATN secondary to bleed, hypotension, hypoperfusion, and contrast administration.
8. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is elevated, and repeat labs are planned to reassess.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Close monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results.
2. Serial CBCs to monitor anemia and blood loss.
3. Replenishment of electrolytes and fluids as needed.
4. Weaning off the ventilator and extubation if possible.
5. Antibiotics and antifungal therapy for potential infection.
6. Management of acute renal failure with fluid and electrolyte management.
7. Free water replacement for hypernatremia.
8. ICU care, including nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

   Assessment and Plan
   74 year old female with recently diagnosed gastric CA, s/p resection,
   transferred from [**Hospital3 4838**] for esophageal stenting, initially
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for respiratory failure [**2-13**] pulmonary edema, then
   extubated and called out to medical floor.  Readmitted to MICU s/p
   pulseless VT/VF arrest, then diagnosed with splenic laceration
   requiring massive transfusion and splenic artery embolization.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Pt has now been intubated 5 times (1)
   hematemasis 2) respiratory distress 3) for ERCP 4)respiratory distress
   following extubation 5) code blue/cardiac arrest with feeble
   respirations. Currently, the patient appears to be volume-overloaded
   and would likely not tolerate extubation without further diruesis.
   -- Diurese with goal net negative 1L today
   -- Continue mechanical ventilation
   .
   # Splenic artery laceration s/p embolization by IR: Hct generally
   stable although slowly trending down.
   -- f/u IR and surgery recommendations
   -- Check Hct Q6H
   -- Transfuse for Hct<30
   -- Maintain active T+S with multiple units crossed
   -- Consider repeat tagged RBC scan if Hct continues to trend down
   .
   # s/p cardiac arrest/probable CAD -- No known cardiac history but echo
   with LV systolic dysfunction c/w CAD, so there is concern for an
   ischemic event as an etiology.
   -- Monitor on telemetry: frequent ectopy but no other events
   -- Cardiac enzymes unchanged
   -- f/u cardiology recs
   -- holding ASA, [**Last Name (un) 284**] in the setting of recent massive bleeding
   -- restart metoprolol
   -- continue atorvastatin
   -- maintain K>4, Mg>2
   .
   # Pericardial effusion: Found on CT chest. Patient is s/p CPR.
   -- Echocardiogram shows fat pad but not effusion
   .
   # CHF: Volume overload
   -- Diurese slowly with goal net negative 1 L today
   .
   # Leukocytosis: WBC up to 22.2.  Could be reaction to acute stress of
   bleed, but also concerning for infection. Have already pulled femoral
   line placed during code.
   -- pan culture
   -- check differential
 shows 88 neutrophils and 5 bands
   -- continue antibiotics (cefepime and fluconazole), consider adding
   gram positive coverage pending culture results
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Differential diagnosis includes ATN,
   obstruction, intraabdominal compartment syndrome.
   -- monitor urine output
   -- maintain renal perfusion
   -- check bladder pressure
   -- renal U/S
   .
   # s/p gastrectomy complicated by anastamotic leak s/p stenting:
   Followed by surgery and GI
   -- restart tube feeding via J-tube
   -- f/u GI and surgery recs
   -- pain meds PRN
   .
   # HTN:
   -- restart metoprolol
   -- holding Diovan in setting of ARF and recent bleeding
   .
   # h/o breast CA
   -- continue Arimidex
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: restart tube feeds, replete lytes aggressively to maintain
   K>4.0, Mg>2.0
   Glycemic Control: insulin SC
   Lines:
   Interval jugular CVL
   Will attempt to place peripherals
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: pneumoboots
   Stress ulcer: pantoprazole
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: family
   Code status: DNR
   Disposition: ICU

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with a complex medical history, including gastric cancer, splenic laceration, cardiac arrest, and pericardial effusion. The patient has been intubated multiple times due to respiratory failure, hematemesis, and respiratory distress.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Intubated, receiving mechanical ventilation, and diuresed with a goal net negative 1L today.
* Cardiovascular: Monitoring on telemetry, frequent ectopy but no other events, and cardiac enzymes unchanged.
* Renal: Acute renal failure, differential diagnosis includes ATN, obstruction, and intraabdominal compartment syndrome, monitoring urine output, maintaining renal perfusion, and checking bladder pressure.
* Hematological: Hct trending down, transfused for Hct <30, and considering repeat tagged RBC scan.
* Gastrointestinal: S/p gastrectomy complicated by anastomotic leak, restarted tube feeds via J-tube, and following up with GI and surgery recommendations.
* Infectious: Pan culture, checking differential, and continuing antibiotics (cefepime and fluconazole), considering adding gram-positive coverage pending culture results.
* Metabolic: Maintaining K > 4.0 and Mg > 2.0, restarting metoprolol, and holding Diovan in setting of ARF and recent bleeding.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: Continued respiratory distress, pneumonia, or ventilator-associated pneumonia.
* Cardiac arrest: Recurrent cardiac arrest, arrhythmias, or cardiogenic shock.
* Acute kidney injury: Progression to chronic kidney disease, electrolyte imbalances, or sepsis.
* Infection: Sepsis, septic shock, or multi-organ dysfunction.
* Gastrointestinal complications: Anastomotic leak, bowel obstruction, or malnutrition.
* Hematological complications: Blood transfusion reactions, hemolytic anemia, or disseminated intravascular coagulation.

The patient's code status is DNR, and the disposition is ICU. The patient requires close monitoring and management of their complex medical conditions to prevent further complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old female with a history of gastric cancer, who has undergone resection and esophageal stenting. She was initially admitted for respiratory failure and pulmonary edema, and subsequently developed splenic laceration requiring massive transfusion and splenic artery embolization. She has been intubated five times and is currently on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. The patient has also experienced episodes of emesis, likely related to the gastrectomy and anastomotic leak.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ongoing respiratory failure may require continued mechanical ventilation and may lead to further complications such as pneumonia, ventilator-associated pneumonia, or respiratory acidosis.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may progress to chronic kidney disease or require dialysis.
3. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and ongoing infection may lead to sepsis, which could worsen her respiratory and cardiovascular status.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and probable CAD may lead to further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or myocardial infarction.
5. Intra-abdominal complications: The patient's gastrectomy and anastomotic leak may lead to further intra-abdominal complications, such as abscesses, fistulas, or bowel obstruction.
6. Bleeding: The patient's ongoing bleeding may lead to further complications, such as hypovolemic shock, coagulopathy, or disseminated intravascular coagulation.
7. Infection: The patient's ongoing infection may lead to further complications, such as sepsis, pneumonia, or urinary tract infection.
8. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and probable CAD may lead to further cardiovascular complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or myocardial infarction.
9. Pulmonary complications: The patient's ongoing respiratory failure may lead to further pulmonary complications, such as pneumonia, ventilator-associated pneumonia, or respiratory acidosis.
10. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's gastrectomy and anastomotic leak may lead to further gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.
